case_name: Jagat Dhish Bhargava v. Jawahar Lal Bhargava

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 222 of 1960 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 222 of 1960.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated December 15, 1959 of Punjab High Court Circuit Bench, Delhi in R.F.A. No. 77-D of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated December 15, 1959, of the Punjab High Court  Circuit Bench , Delhi, in R. F. Appeal No. 77-D of 1954.

facts.text: Agreement of sale entered between Gokal Dhish Bhargava and appellant Jagat Dhish Bhargava for one third of the one fourth share in the property.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that an agreement of sale of one third of the one fourth share in the property companyered by the document was entered into between Gokal Dhish Bhargava and the appellant Jagat Dhish Bhargava.

facts.text: Gokal Dhish Bhargava sued appellant and respondents 8 and 9 for specific performance in Court of Senior Civil Judge, New Delhi, Civil Suit No. 684/128 of 1949/50.

anchor.surface_text: Gokal Dhish Bhargava sued the appel- lant and pro forms respondents 8 and 9 for specific performance of the said agreement of sale in the Court of the Senior Civil Judge, New Delhi  Civil Suit No. 684/128 of 1949/50 .

facts.text: Suit dismissed on March 12, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: This suit was dismissed on March 12, 1954. ,

facts.text: Pending trial court decision, Gokal Dhish Bhargava died and his son Jawahar Lal Bhargava (respondent 1) and Chunni Lal Bhargava brought on record as legal representatives.

anchor.surface_text: Pending decision in the trial companyrt Gokal Dhish Bhargava  fled and his son Jawahar Lal Bhargava, respondent 1 and Chunni Lal Bhargava were brought on the record as legal representatives.

facts.text: After suit dismissal and before appeal, Chunni Lal Bhargava died; respondents 2 to 7 as his legal representatives joined respondent 1 in preferring appeal.

anchor.surface_text: After the suit was dismissed and before the appeal in question was preferred in the High Court Chunni Lal Bhargava died thereupon respondents 2 to 7, as his legal representatives, joined respondent 1 in preferring an appeal against the said decree in the High Court of Punjab.

facts.text: Memo of appeal with judgment and taxed bill of costs filed in High Court on July 29, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The memo of appeal along with the judgment dismissing the suit and the taxed bill of companyts endorsed on the back of the last page of the judgment was filed in the High Court on July 29, 1954.

facts.text: On March 24, 1954, respondents 2 to 7 applied for certified copy of judgment and decree.

anchor.surface_text: The record shows that on March 24,1954, an application was made by respondents 2 to 7  who will be called the respondents hereafter  for a certified companyy of the judgment and decree passed in the said suit for specific performance.

facts.text: Certified copy of judgment and bill of costs supplied, but no decree drawn up so no copy supplied.

anchor.surface_text: A certified companyy of the judgment and the bill of companyts was supplied to them but the decree had number been drawn up and numbercopy of the decree was therefore supplied to them.

facts.text: On August 2, 1954, Assistant Registrar returned memo of appeal as defective without decree copy.

anchor.surface_text: On August 2, 1954, the Assistant Registrar of the High Court returned the memo of appeal filed by the respondents to their companynsel and pointed out to him that since numbercopy of the decree had been filed the presentation of the appeal was defective and the defect needed to be rectified.

facts.text: Appeal refiled on August 16, 1954 with endorsement that no decree drawn up.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, on August 16, 1954, the respondents companynsel refiled the appeal with an endorsement that a memo of companyts alone had been prepared by the trial companyrt and numberdecree had been drawn up, and so the appeal should be held to be properly filed.

facts.text: Appeal registered as No. 77-D of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Apparently this explanation was treated as satisfactory by the office of the High Court and the appeal was registered as No. 77-D of 1954.

facts.text: Appeal admitted by Dulat, J. on August 30, 1954 under O.41 r.11.

anchor.surface_text: In due companyrse the appeal was placed for preliminary hearing under 0. 41, r. 11 of the Code of Civil Procedure before Dulat, J. who admitted it on August 30, 1954.

facts.text: Appeal put up for hearing on December 26, 1958 before Circuit Bench.

anchor.surface_text: Ultimately when the appeal became ready for hearing it was put up on the Board of the Circuit Bench of the High Court to be heard on December 26, 1958.

facts.text: Appellant served notice on respondents' counsel on December 23, 1958 raising preliminary objection on competence.

anchor.surface_text: Meanwhile on December 23., 1958, the appellant served a numberice on the respondents companynsel intimating to him that he proposed to raise a preliminary objection against the companypetence of the appeal on the ground that the decree under appeal had number been filed as required under 0. 41, r. 1 along with the memo of appeal and the certified companyy of the judgment.

facts.text: On December 24, 1958, respondents moved trial court for drawing up decree, but infructuous as record sent to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Next day, that is to say on December 24, 1958, the respondents moved the trial Court for drawing up of the decree, but since the record had in the meantime been sent by the trial Court to the High Court numberdecree companyld be drawn up by the trial Court, and so the motion became infructuous.

facts.text: Appeal not heard on December 26, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal, however, did number reach hearing on December 26, 1958.

facts.text: On December 29, 1958, respondents moved court for declaration of maintainability or to send record for decree.

anchor.surface_text: On December 29, 1958, the respondents moved the Court that the appeal should be declared to be maintainable as the memo of companyts which alone had been prepared by the trial Court read along with the companycluding paragraph of the judgment may be held to satisfy the requirements of the decree in the alternative they prayed that the record of the suit in the trial Court should be sent for to enable them to get a decree prepared with a view to file the same in the High Court along with their appeal.

facts.text: Bishan Narain, J. directed application to be heard by appeal bench.

anchor.surface_text: Bishan Narain, J., before whom this application was taken out for orders, directed that it may be heard by the Bench which would hear the appeal.

facts.text: Appeal heard by Falshaw and Chopra, JJ. on December 8, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Eventually the appeal came on for hearing before Falshaw and Chopra, JJ. on De ember 8, 1959.

facts.text: High Court on December 15, 1959 rejected appellant's preliminary objection and allowed one month's time to get decree copy.

anchor.surface_text: This preliminary objection was, however, number upheld by the High Court, and it was held that the proper companyrse to follow was to allow the respondents a months time for the purpose of getting a decree drawn up in the proper form by the lower Court and obtaining a companyy thereof . Accordingly the record which had in the meanwhile been received by the High Court after the appeal was admitted under 0. 41, r. 11 was ordered to be sent back to the lower Court without delay.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal by special leave against High Court order of December 15, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: It is against this order which was passed by the High Court on December 15, 1959, that the present appeal by special leave has been filed.

facts.text: Certified copy of decree obtained and filed by respondents on December 23, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: The problem thus posed by the appellant for our decision has number become academic because subsequent to the decision of the High Court under appeal the respondents have in fact obtained Po certified companyy of the decree on December 23, 1959, and have filed it in the High Court on the same day.

facts.text: No decree was drawn up by trial court after judgment.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case the respondents had applied for a certified companyy of the judgment as well as the decree in the trial Court on March 24, 1954, and they were number given a companyy of the decree for the simple reason that numberdecree was drawn up

facts.text: Supreme Court held appeal presentation on December 23, 1959 in time under s.12(2) Limitation Act excluding time for obtaining decree copy.

anchor.surface_text: The position, therefore, is that when the certified companyy of the decree was filed by the respondents in the High Court on December 23, 1969, the whole of the period between the date of the application for the certified companyy and the date when the decree was actually signed would have to be excluded under s. 12, sub-s.  2 . Inevitably the presentation of the appeal on December 23, 1959 would be in time.

anchor.surface_text: The position of law under O. 41, r. 1 is absolutely clear. arguments.claim: Drawing up decree is duty of trial court office under s.33 CPC, O20 rr.3-7; litigant has no control

anchor.surface_text: Section 33 of the Code of Civil Procedure requires that the Court, after the case has been heard, shall pronounce judgment, and on such judgment a decree shall follow. Order 20, r. 3 provides, inter alia, that the judgment shall be dated and signed by the judge in the open Court at the time of pronouncing it,

holdings.text: The requirements of Order 41 Rule 1 CPC that the appeal be accompanied by a copy of the decree appealed from are mandatory, and in the absence of the decree the filing of the appeal would be incomplete, defective and incompetent.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore there is no doubt that the requirements that the decree should be filed along with the memorandum of appeal is mandatory, and in the absence of the decree the filing of the appeal would be incomplete, defective and incompetent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual interpretation of O.41 r.1 CPC; appeal is against decree, not judgment; limitation runs from decree date per Art.156 Lim Act.

holdings.text: When certified copy of decree filed on December 23, 1959, the period from application for certified copy to signing of decree excluded under s.12(2) Limitation Act; presentation of appeal in time.

anchor.surface_text: The position, therefore, is that when the certified copy of the decree was filed by the respondents in the High Court on December 23, 1959, the whole of the period between the date of the application for the certified copy and the date when the decree was actually signed would have to be excluded under s. 12, sub-s. 2 . Inevitably the presentation of the appeal on December 23, 1959 would be in time.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application made before decree drawn up; time requisite includes drawing up time; consensus of authorities; act of court no injury.

holdings.text: The appeal preferred by respondents on December 23, 1959 is proper and in time and can be dealt with in accordance with law.

anchor.surface_text: The result is that the appeal preferred by the respondents on December 23, 1959, is proper and in time and it can not be dealt with in accordance with law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Decree copy filed; limitation computed excluding requisite time due to court office delay; no fault of appellant.

holdings.text: No hard and fast rule of general applicability for dealing with appeals defectively filed under O.41 r.1 CPC; appropriate orders case-by-case, scrutinize at initial stage and require remedy of defects.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes cases based on whether decree drawn/applied timely; if no decree and timely application, treat as premature, allow cure; faults court offices; fairness over rigidity; notes Punjab HC conflict.

holdings.text: High Court order allowing time to obtain and file certified copy of decree is fair, just and correct.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Given trial court and High Court office negligence; respondents not at fault; aligns with no prejudice from court acts.

holdings.text: Litigant not penalized for default or negligence of court or its officers in drawing up decree; act of court does no injury.

anchor.surface_text: As observed by Cairnes, L. C. in Rodger v. Comptoir dEscompte de Paris as early as 1871 one of the first and highest duties of all Courts is to take care that the act of the Court does no injury to any of the suitors.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent application; protects against court delay in decree preparation when timely application made.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore there is no doubt that the requirements that the decree should be filed along with the memorandum of appeal is mandatory, and in the absence of the decree the filing of the appeal would be incomplete, defective and incompetent.

Therefore there is no doubt that the requirements that the decree should be filed along with the memorandum of appeal is mandatory, and in the absence of the decree the filing of the appeal would be incomplete, defective and incompetent.

The position, therefore, is that when the certified copy of the decree was filed by the respondents in the High Court on December 23, 1959, the whole of the period between the date of the application for the certified copy and the date when the decree was actually signed would have to be excluded under s. 12, sub-s. 2 . Inevitably the presentation of the appeal on December 23, 1959 would be in time.

The position, therefore, is that when the certified copy of the decree was filed by the respondents in the High Court on December 23, 1959, the whole of the period between the date of the application for the certified copy and the date when the decree was actually signed would have to be excluded under s. 12, sub-s. 2 . Inevitably the presentation of the appeal on December 23, 1959 would be in time.

anchor.surface_text: As observed by Cairnes, L. C. in Rodger v. Comptoir dEscompte de Paris as early as 1871 one of the first and highest duties of all Courts is to take care that the act of the Court does no injury to any of the suitors.

Precedent supports the argument invoking the act of court maxim, as it originates from that case.
Precedent Rodger v Comptoir dEscompte de Paris is the foundational case establishing the principle that act of court does no injury, as reflected in the concept description.
Precedent supports the holding by providing authoritative basis for the no injury principle applied to court delay.
Precedent supports resolution of the issue through the duty of courts not to injure suitors via their acts.
